intro.text: Like many girls her age, your average American tween loves to keep up with the latest fashion trends and explore new ways to express herself.
“Junior’s” clothing lines often channel this interest with youthful styles that fit young girls as they grow. The median 11-year-old typically wears a size Medium in the Junior’s section.

But not all tweens wear the same size. If we were to look at a sample of all 10- and 11-year-old girls in the U.S., here are the Junior’s sizes that match up with their body measurements. Notice that there are sizes available for most girls in this age group.

intro.text: By age 15, most girls have gone through growth spurts and puberty, and they’ve reached their adult height. Many have started to outgrow the Junior’s size section.

intro.text: By their 20s, a size Medium will no longer reflect the median or average woman’s waistline.
Instead, the median 20-something fits a Large. In women’s numeric sizing, that translates to about a size 14.
Sizing options are even worse when you look at all adult women over the age of 20. The median woman in the U.S. fits around a size 18 based on their waistline measurement.

It’s not guaranteed that a size 18 garment would actually fit her though. A woman’s waistline is just one of many important measurements. Other factors like the cut of the garment or the amount of stretch in the fabrics will heavily influence the fit. And as we’ll see more later on, sizes are wildly inconsistent across major clothing brands. Still size charts are typically meant to reflect the baseline body measurements for any style of clothing. What we’re seeing is that those baseline measurements are largely out of sync with the true proportions of American women today.
The bulk of sizes are concentrated on a sliver of the female population. Only the smallest 10 percent of adult women in the U.S. are a size 8 or below.
On top of it all, only a small portion of brands carry sizes larger than a size 16. That leaves over half of all women without sizing options at all.

titlePage.subtitle: Women’s clothing sizes often fit 15-year-olds better than adults

text.value: Junior-specific clothing lines were meant to reflect the differences between growing adolescents and adult women whose proportions are typically fuller in the hips and bust. The idea was that once a girl matured, she could easily transition out of the Junior’s section (where size labels are odd numbers: 1, 3, 5 etc.) and find her corresponding size made for adults (which are even-numbered: 2, 4, 6 etc.).
For that sizing system to work, one thing needed to be true: Adult women must have roughly the same body proportions as teenage girls, but with slightly more curves.

But most modern adults do not look like teenagers — nor probably should they. This means that as women progress through life — as they launch careers, start families, or grow within their communities — the range of accessible clothing options will become smaller and smaller. Many, if not most, will have no available sizing options at all.
For a lot of women, that cycle starts as early as age 16.

textA.value: In 1941, the U.S. government set out to standardize clothing sizes based on the body measurements of thousands of women. The garment industry had exploded following the industrial revolution, but the approach to sizing was less a science and more trial-and-error, researchers noted at the time. They found huge variations in garment sizes across different manufacturers. Alterations were also prohibitively expensive. When garments couldn’t be tailored or simply didn’t fit, a large number of women had to return items to the store, ratcheting up costs for all parties involved.
“This means a loss of money and good will to the retailer and annoyance and waste of time to the woman purchaser,” wrote the report’s chief researcher, Ruth O’Brien.

Over 85 years later, and many of those same problems and annoyances are just as true — if not worse today. Inconsistent sizing, costly alterations, and high rates of item returns are considered norms by modern shopping standards. More often than not, ill-fitting clothes pile up in our closets and in landfills, fueling a vicious cycle that treats garments as disposable.
If generation after generation of women have faced the same, persistent struggles, one must ask: Is it even possible to mass-produce clothes that fit all types of bodies?

textB.value: One of the chief problems is that our modern sizing system is based on the body proportions of a single group: White women.

O’Brien, a trained scientist and head of the Clothing and Textiles Division within the U.S. Bureau of Home Economics, broke new ground with her 1941 study by using a scientific approach to sizing. For likely the first time ever, the garment industry had hard data to use as a foundation for all garments through the body measurements of the roughly 14,700 women who participated in the study.

The study’s sample size, however, was in no way representative of the broader population. Participants were mostly young, middle class white women from urban areas within just a handful of states. No women of color were included.

This matters because today we know that age and race factor heavily into how our bodies are shaped. Genetics can play a huge role in determining each person’s proportions, their bone structure, how they build muscle mass, and where they tend to store fat on their bodies. Scholars have identified as many as nine different categories of body proportions commonly found among adult women alone, many of which are likely familiar to the countless women told over the years to “dress for their body type.”
Only one body type, however, serves as the underlying blueprint for nearly every piece of women’s clothing: The hourglass silhouette.

proportionsIntro.title: do not fit
proportionsIntro.text:
The hourglass silhouette is often characterized as an idealized version of western beauty standards. It emphasizes fullness in both the bust and hips, with a waistline that is exactly 10 inches smaller than those two measurements.

The problem is that women are rarely born with those precise proportions. One study found that only 30% of American women actually have a true hourglass figure.

Here’s how that impacts the type of clothes that most adults are able to wear.

proportions.text: If we were to take the waist and hip measurements of the median woman in the U.S., here’s how those proportions around the torso would look like.

Let’s say that our typical adult woman goes shopping at J.Crew.

If she were to try on a pair of pants that fit her waist, she would likely fit a size 18.

Doing so, however, would mean that the pants are too big in the hips by six inches.

If she instead picked out pants that fit around her backside, she would have the opposite problem as before.

Here, a size 12 would fit her hips best, but then the waist would be too small by more than six inches.

J.Crew is hardly an outlier.

Many mainstream fashion brands there to be a10-inch difference between a woman’s waist and hip measurements.

Compare that to the median woman in the U.S., who has just over a four-inch difference between her waist and hip.

Surprisingly, these exaggerated proportions are fixed across entire size ranges.

If you compared the smallest size to the largest size in a range, both would have the same 10-inch difference between the waistline and their corresponding hip measurements.

Put another way: Clothing sizes expect all women, large or small, to share the exact same body shape.

But that’s not how women’s bodies work

vanityIntro.title: vanity sizing
vanityIntro.text:
Many things have changed since the WWII-era efforts to create standardized sizing, chief among them: Americans are larger today than they were in the past.Over the past three decades alone, the median American woman’s waistline has increased by nearly four inches. And as waistlines have gotten larger, so too have clothing sizes.

Though the U.S. government has long-abandoned its attempts to make universal clothing sizes for women, an organization called ASTM International has filled this role by releasing technical standards for size ranges every few years

To see that change, take a look at ASTM’s standard sizes from 1995.

vanitySizing.text: About 30 years ago, there was a 12.5-inch spread of waistline measurements separating the smallest size 2 (24 inches) and the largest size 20 (36.5 inches).

Today, that gap is 15.2 inches between the smallest size 00 (25.38 inches) and the largest size (40 inches)

While additional sizes for 00 and 0 were added in the early 2000s, all waistline measurements today are larger regardless of size.

Notice how in 1995, a 27-inch waist was considered a size 8.

But in 2021 it was between sizes 2 and 4.

By comparison, today’s size 8 is 2.5 inches bigger in the waist than it was 30 years ago.

This is vanity sizing in action.

Vanity sizing is a frequent villain within the consumer mindset for its role in driving sizing inconsistencies across the fashion industry.

Over the decades, a behavioral trend started to emerge where women seemed more likely to buy clothes if the labels were marked as sizes smaller than they actually were. Researchers have found that many women often ascribe an identity around clothing sizes (“I am a size 4” versus “I wear a size 4”). Any deviation from that specific size may then pose a threat to not just their ego, but who they are as a person. Rather than size up, consumers would prefer to either go home empty-handed or purchase other items that enhance aesthetics, but aren’t tied to sizes, like beauty products.

Brands, and the apparel industry at large, responded by slowly inflating sizes. What was once a size 6 is now labeled a size 4, and so on and so on.

That’s left us with a sizing system that’s all over the place. But then without vanity sizing, average Americans would have even fewer sizing options than they do now. .
Between 1988 and 1994, the average woman’s waistline was 34.88 inches. By 2023, it was 37.68 inches
In both cases — 30 years ago on to today —the median waistline roughly lined up with the size 18 that was available at that time (if at all).

ASTMtransition.subhed: Mass-produced clothes don’t fit every body
ASTMtransition.text:
While vanity sizing and broader industry trends have translated into sizes that are now larger than before, the changes still continue to skew toward serving the smallest women. Today, just as we saw 30 years ago, nearly half of the population is shut out of buying clothes from some of the most popular or well known brands.

In many ways, this has been intentional.

ASTM has said itself that it’s not trying to develop sizing standards that accurately reflect the full scope of modern demographics in America. Instead, the system is just as much tailored to conventional beauty standards and what clothing brands consider to be their ideal customer.

“It is important to note that the body measurements herein have been derived from designer experience and market observations and cross checked with available databases in the attempt to identify current customer characteristics and changing proportions and not from new nationwide anthropometric research. —ASTM’s 1995 standardized sizing chart

Fashion and clothing brands aren’t required to align with universal sizing standards.

If they so choose, a brand can tailor its size charts to include more historically underrepresented populations — and some do, to a degree. Many do not.

The result — as many women have likely experienced — has meant that sizes are all over the map.

sizeCharts.text:
Many prominent (particularly high-end) brands do not carry sizes higher than a size 14 or 16.

These size ranges are often smaller than both the average woman’s waistline of 37.68 inches and ASTM guides.
Some brands carry extended options within their “Regular” or “Straight” size ranges.
While others have a “Plus” size range that is kept separate, often with simpler styles that differ from other straight size collections.
